titleStmt.title: T.H. Lacy's Acting Edition of Victorian Plays (1848-1873) : a bibliography
titleStmt.author: Revised and extended by Lou Burnard

sourceDesc.p: This is an enhanced and extended version of the catalogue of Lacy's Acting Edition originally created by the Victorian Plays Project (VPP), made by screen-scraping and re-encoding data archived at the VPP_website at NUI Galway. (These modernized PDFs are also available from YUMPU)

The catalogue has been cross-checked against several other contemporary sources. Various minor errors and inconsistencies have been corrected, and additional information added, particularly about available digitizations of the plays.

Authors' names have been standardised, in the form "Surname, Forenames-or-initials" following the most frequent usage in cases of doubt. Square brackets are used to indicate that the author name contained within them is not attested on the titlepage of the work in question; the attribute resp is used to indicate the grounds for making the attribution, and takes one of the following values:
btao: ("By The Author Of") the title is listed in a btao indication somewhere
ATC: attribution is made in the Adelphi Theatre Catalog
msnote: attribution is made by manuscript annotation on a library copy
nicoll: attribution made in Allardyce Nicoll's Handlist
When no author is given and none has been plausibly identified, the author is given as "[Anon.]"

Several title elements may be present, corresponding with different parts of the title page. The main title has no @type attribute; other values used are:
sub: a subtitle
source: indicates that the title is an adaptation or translation
btao: the title contains a list of other titles by the same author For example: [Robertson, T.W.; Reade, Charles] The Lost Husband A Drama in four acts Written and Adapted from the French by the author of The ladies' battle

The selection of titles making up each volume seems to have changed very little during the course their long printing history. Certainly the lists of titles which appear occasionally in the printed volumes show little variation. I have identified a small number of titles which change between their first appearance -- if we are to believe the printed lists -- and their appearance in the 93 volume HathiTrust edition digitized by Google from a copy at the University of Michigan. They are listed below in a bibl with the status attribute set to replaced. The texts which replaced them are also described below; they have the same number (e.g. 12.2), but their identifier is suffixed with an R. For example, the sixth title in volume 1 has two versions, both given the number 1.6. In the advertising pages consulted, this title is text L0006, Bayly's Ladder of Love. However, in the HT edition, the sixth title in volume 1 is Murray's No!, to which we therefore give the identifier L0006R. A list of these modifications is given below.

prefixDef.ab: URLs using this prefix point to a PDF format file as distributed by the VPP_in Galway
URLs using this prefix point to an HTML transcription from Project Gutenberg
URLs using this prefix point to a set of page images available from the Internet Archive
URLs using this prefix point to a set of page images available from the Internet Archive
URLs using this prefix point to a locally stored copy of the resource indicated

bibl.author: [Taylor, Tom]
[Smith, Albert R.]
bibl.note: The identification of the authors of this play is complicated: the play text describes it as 'by the authors of "Valentine and Orson", "Whittington and his Cat", "Cinderella" etc.'. Nicoll lists Tom Taylor and A.R. Smith as the authors, but has T.P. Taylor as the author of "Cinderella" and Mark Lemon as the author of "Whittington and his Cat"; further to complicate matters, Princeton University Library holds a copy of the title wrapper of the play with the following inscription: '“A” This is the Drama marked “A” referred to in the Affidavit of Charles Reade sworn before me this --th day of December.—[unsigned].' Also inscribed on t.p.: 'Fredk Bidwell'.

bibl.author: Barnett, Morris
bibl.title: Power and Principle

bibl.author: [Taylor, Tom]
[Coyne, J. Stirling]
bibl.note: J. Stirling Coyne is listed as the author of a play of this title on the title-page of his play "My Wife's Daughter" also in this Volume. However, in Volume 1, the anonymous play, "The Philosopher's Stone" is attributed to the author of "The Vicar of Wakefield" and "Diogenes", whilst "Diogenes" (Volume 1) is attributed to the author of "Parents and Guardians". This latter is known to be by Tom Taylor, and Nicoll lists Taylor as the author also of "The Vicar of Wakefield". It is plausible that this play was co-authored by Taylor and Stirling Coyne, although they are not known to have collaborated on anything else. "Sir Roger de Coverley" (Taylor) (Volume 4) is also listed as being by the author of "Diogenes", "The Vicar of Wakefield", "The Philosopher's Stone", and "Prince Dorus".

div.p: Dates given are those of the first performance, according to the copy.

div.p: The above table suggests that the replacement titles were almost always much older works, presumably available in house to replace any play which we may hypothesize Lacy had been cautioned against including since he had lost (or never held) the rights to it.
